sec.title: Robustness Checks
sec.p: I performed a number of robustness checks dealing with the sample and model structure. First, to prevent misclassification errors, the results presented here excluded all firms with fewer than four flat panel patents throughout their entire history. Changing or eliminating the minimum number of patents does not change the results. Second, as noted in footnote 4, I set up the model as a two-stage analysis, first predicting whether the firm remains active in flat panel display patenting and then predicting annual LCD patenting. This is an alternate way of addressing selection concerns and produces the same results. Third, I have tested aggregated models with only one observation per firm (as opposed to a full panel structure), since many of the primary variables of interest are time-invariant across the post-1982 period. In this case, I used the first five years of firm-level data to categorize the firm and then predicted all future years in aggregate. The results are similar to the models reported here. Fourth, there may be legitimate concern about the endogeneity of the primary independent variables in this study. There is little that I can do about the endogeneity of which technology early-entrant firms chose to pursue, but looking at the firms in the data suggests that there were a roughly equal number of firms from each region and with each type of background (i.e., computer versus television) making each early technological choice. In addition, there are a number of firms that would be identified as “high quality” firms supporting plasma initially (such as NEC, IBM, and Fujitsu), and the failure of plasma as a candidate for the overall dominant design was not due to poor support from its sponsors but, instead, was related to the realities of the two technologies. Thus the endogeneity of technological choice does not appear to be an issue. The endogeneity that is of some real concern, though, is the endogeneity of entry timing, because firms entering earlier may have a greater strategic imperative to succeed in the industry (Mitchell, 1989). To deal with this source of endogeneity, I evaluated models focusing only on early-entrant firms. The results of the model are reported in model 2 of table 3 and show that the core findings hold true for this sample as well.

Table 3 contains a number of other robustness checks, as well. In general, none of these tests produce significant changes in the core results. In model 3, I excluded the plasma patent stock variable to ensure that multicolinearity between this variable and the technology choice at entry was not driving the results. In model 4, I excluded all observations without sales data, as there may be concerns that selection biases associated with having almost 50 percent small firms (and therefore with unobserved sales data) may be affecting the results. In model 5, I used only the first two years of post-entry data to categorize early entrants based on which technology they supported, though this dramatically decreases the number of firms supporting both technologies. The remaining robustness checks entail alternate model specifications. Model 6 tests a standard negative binomial regression (not a GEE model) with clustered standard errors. Model 7 adds firm-level random effects to the standard negative binomial model. Model 8 uses a Poisson model instead of a negative binomial and includes firm-level random effects as well. All of these models show similar results, with the exception of the coefficient on enter with both in models 4 and 8, which is nonsignificant. Additionally, I performed multiple robustness checks with respect to the time spans of the panels modeled here. First, I modified the start date of the primary panel (currently 1970 to deal with the sparseness of the data before that year) between 1965 and 1975 without any changes to the core results. Second, I modified the start date for the plasma patent panel (to test H2, currently set at 1989 as plasma began its resurgence) from 1985 to 1993 without any change in the primary results. Third, I modified the time distinguishing between early and late entrants (currently set at 1983). Given the growth in the LCD patent curve and the qualitative data from my sources, a time between 1981 and 1985 seems most appropriate, and any cut-off date in this range produces similar results.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This research theorized and empirically investigated the implications of technological choices in the context of competing technologies. Specifically, I examined the learning-based consequences of betting on the right horse early, the right horse late, the wrong horse early, or both horses simultaneously. The central finding is that initial investment in a failed technology reduces subsequent knowledge creation ability in the emerging dominant technology. This inertia is not eliminated by simultaneous support for both technologies, and it even extends to the reemergence of the same technology later. The quantitative and qualitative results suggest that the inertia is driven by inferences drawn by managers of the expected value of the uncertain industry that result in lowered effort, investment, and knowledge creation by the firms that initially supported the losing technology. The possession of relevant complementary assets—which should increase organizational incentives to pursue the winning technology—moderate but do not alleviate the inertial effects of failure.

This study makes three primary contributions. First, it extends work on reinforcement learning in organizations (Denrell and March, 2001) and learning from failure (Haunschild and Rhee, 2004; Baumard and Starbuck, 2005) by focusing on how failure in one technology may have organizational implications in a related technology. This shifts the focus of failure-based learning from the question of whether failure helps prevent future similar failures (Cannon and Edmondson, 2001; Haunschild and Sullivan, 2002) to the question of how failure affects the broader organization. Second, the study draws on the relationships between resource partitioning and both innovation (Mezias and Mezias, 2000) and learning (Barnett, Greve, and Park, 1994) to argue that betting on multiple technologies at once will not eliminate inertia. This suggests that further research on the innovativeness of generalists and specialists, especially how this relates to performance in innovation-intensive industries, may be fruitful. Third, through these two primary theoretical contributions, the study offers an important look at the firm-level implications of technological choices made under conditions of technological competition. In this respect, the study offers important caveats on existing prescriptive research on how flexible firms should be in response to technological change by highlighting the important downsides of making a failed technological bet. Thus the study has implications for three streams of research: technological change, learning from failure, and resource partitioning.

sec.title: Implications for Technological Change and Evolution
sec.p: This study’s implications for literatures on first-mover advantage (e.g., Franco et al., 2009) and firm adaptation to technological change (e.g., Eggers and Kaplan, 2009) are similar. In both cases, researchers have traditionally selected on successful new industries and technologies. It would seem, however, that any potential desirability of being an early entrant to an industry or being responsive to external technological change is highly dependent on making the right choice (Christensen, Suárez, and Utterback, 1998). Firms adopting the right new technology early may be advantaged in their ability to build a strong market position, but making the wrong choice (even if the firm supports the right technology at the same time) can dilute or eliminate the potential for advantage. The idea that the risk of failure has implications for the decision about whether more adaptive firms can create an advantage has been obliquely addressed in terms of the downside of adapting an early and inefficient generation of a new technology (Bohlmann, Golder, and Mitra, 2002) or the risks of abruptly evolving technological industries (Suárez and Lanzolla, 2007). But without a full consideration of the risks of failure and its long-term consequences, we as scholars are not in a position to offer prescriptive advice about when and how managers should seek first-mover advantages or be responsive to technological change.

While this study highlights the need to consider the potential failure of technological investments in any study about adaptation or flexibility, and it offers a first look at the inertial effects resulting from failure, more work is needed to understand how this process plays out further downstream by looking at product- and firm-level outcomes. As a means of mitigating the effects of failed investments on future decision making, this study validates the role of complementary assets in helping firms survive technological discontinuities in the knowledge space, in addition to the product space (Tripsas, 1997). This broadens our understanding of the potential value of complementary assets for decision making and knowledge creation, but further work on exactly how the possession of complementary assets affects outcomes would facilitate understanding of their value. More generally, a deeper investigation into how firms are able to recover from failed investments is needed, and such work would contribute greatly to our understanding of strategic renewal and industry evolution (Agarwal and Helfat, 2009).

Additionally, though not a core focus of this paper, the idea of firms making parallel investments in multiple competing technologies raises interesting and novel questions. Most research on search in general and technological search specifically does not consider the potential hedging behavior of firms. The fact that these firms actually display different behavior than those that focused on the winning technology from the start suggests that a classic real-options approach to technological search management may not be as effective in practice as in theory and that the management of the entire portfolio of choices may not be as simple as originally conceived (Eggers, 2012). More research is needed on the factors that lead firms to search down multiple competing paths simultaneously and the consequences of such behavior, as this behavior is an understudied but potentially vital aspect of how firms deal with technological uncertainty.

sec.title: Implications for Learning from Failure and Reinforcement Learning
sec.p: For the core theory behind the first hypothesis, this study drew on the literatures on learning from failure and reinforcement learning. Many of these issues have been investigated either through simulation (Denrell and March, 2001) or qualitative research (Baumard and Starbuck, 2005). There has been comparatively limited large-scale empirical investigation, and what exists largely focuses on organizations learning to prevent similar failures in the future (Haunschild and Sullivan, 2002; Haunschild and Rhee, 2004). By comparison, this study suggests that we need to know more about the broader organizational and longer-term implications of failures for decision making, knowledge-creation, and performance.

Such a broad perspective on the effects of failure raises an interesting question. Most of the literature mentioned above suggests that failures are bad for the organization, as they may generate improper inferences that limit learning potential, and this aligns with Noda and Collis’s (2001: 922) suggestion that “an initial unfavorable experience will create a downward spiral of failure.” By contrast, some studies have focused on the potential benefits of technological failures, specifically Henderson and Stern (2004), with their theory of partial external selection, and Burgelman (1994, 2002), with his discussion of how failure in memory chips led Intel to success in microprocessors. Similarly, work on performance below aspirations (not identical to specific failures, but a likely result of failures) suggests that such low performance is an important mechanism to jar firms from path-dependent and potentially destructive processes (March and Heath, 1994; Greve, 2003). How can we align these different perspectives on failure?

One answer may be related to the location of the failure. The modeling work by Denrell and March (2001) and the core idea of a failure trap as described by Levinthal and March (1993) and Noda and Collis (2001) all focus on the initial failure as being in a new domain about which the firm has little direct knowledge and very weak prior expectations. This failure leads to reducing those prior expectations in a way that closes off that avenue of search but also decreases performance and thus necessitates exploratory search again. By contrast, the idea of problem-driven search brings the organization back to exploitation as its focus, suggesting that the source of the problem is in a core domain in which exploitation can be used to solve it. As Cyert and March (1963: 34) said, “failure-induced search increases efficiency and reduces foolishness” and cuts back on “activities . . . for which the connection with major goals is difficult to calculate concretely (e.g., research in many firms)” (p. 171). Thus failure in a core area for the firm may be perceived differently from failure in a new area. The current study looks specifically at failure in a new area for the firm, but a broader investigation into how the domain of the failed efforts affects recovery, motivation, and search behavior would help to clarify when and why failure may be good or bad for an organization.

sec.title: Implications for Resource Partitioning
sec.p: To explain why betting on both uncertain technologies simultaneously may not be the perfect answer for firms facing competing technologies, this study draws on the literature on resource partitioning and learning. Generalists—those firms that bet on multiple technologies—are liable to learn less from their own experiences and to be less successful in innovation during early periods of industry growth (Mezias and Mezias, 2000) than are specialists that focus on the winning technology from the start. To the extent that this perspective is correct, a broader suggestion might be that generalist firms would deal poorly with environmental change and uncertainty. This would result not simply from being large firms, but because their organizational breadth reduces incentives to learn and adapt to changing conditions (Morris and Moore, 2000) and because the internal complexity of the firm makes adaptation and communication challenging (Haunschild and Sullivan, 2002). The results of the inertia of technological generalists in this study hold even when controlling for potential correlates with the mechanisms above, such as organizational size and pre-entry experience. This suggests that being a technological generalist may have an effect on flexibility and adaptation in the context of technological change and uncertainty. In fact, pre-entry experience in affected industries was suggested in this study as a source of downstream complementary assets that would increase incentives for knowledge creation in the winning technology, but it also may increase organizational complexity in ways that limit coordination and adaptation. These countervailing effects may explain why pre-entry experience was helpful to firms that specialized in plasma initially, but not for firms that were technological generalists. More work to tease out this generalist versus specialist phenomenon in the context of technological change is warranted, specifically either to align this perspective with existing models of incumbents’ inertia in technological change (e.g., an incentive-based view; Kaplan and Henderson, 2005) or to establish its independence as a mechanism for inertia.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: This study, of course, has its limitations. Some are typical limitations for similar studies, such as testing data only within a single industry that may limit the generalizability of the results and the use of patent data as a proxy for knowledge creation. Both are concerns, but unavoidable when investigating the questions asked in this research. A larger issue is the inability to measure the intervening processes between failure and reduced knowledge generation. Based on work on reinforcement learning, the mechanism is presumed to be based on learning and the drawing of inferences that then result in organizational changes in policy and resource allocation. This is the central argument of the paper, but it can only be made by excluding other explanations for the observed data. In the end, I believe that such behavioral explanations are the only explanations that fit the data, but this does require a leap of faith. Future work might further investigate the mechanisms that lead to inertial behavior, qualitatively within organizations to understand the processes and interactions, via experimental methods testing multilevel hypotheses about inefficiencies, or through careful consideration of theory on individual- and group-level biases. All of these would provide a more nuanced understanding of where inertia comes from. Additionally, there may be concerns about the limited scale of the failure tested here. For many firms, the failed investment was financing a handful of patents in a technology that bore no fruit. Often, failures are much more costly and significant, as firms invest money in manufacturing, marketing, and distribution before receiving little or no return—high technology products like the Apple Newton and the Pioneer Laser Disc player come to mind. Yet it seems that the smaller scale of the failure evaluated in this study offers a strong test of the theory, as this is a circumstance in which we would least expect to see changes in decision-making behavior based on the failure. It would still be helpful to investigate failure in other contexts to answer questions about generalizability and to provide insight into broader ranges of failed investments.

sec.title: Generalizing These Findings on Failure and Inertia
sec.p: Although this paper focused on technological choices specifically, the proposed mechanisms that lead to the observed inertial response to failure are more general. As such, they might logically be applied to any type of failed investments beyond technology and have important implications for the broad literature on learning from failure (Cannon and Edmondson, 2001; Baumard and Starbuck, 2005). Though I believe the findings of this study will hold beyond the bounds of technological failure, it is important to point out specific boundary conditions based on prior research and logic that may exist for such broader application. First, there would need to be a link between the failed investment and the future decision being made. Prior work on learning from failure has shown that attempts to learn from failure do not produce far-reaching changes in behavior but, instead, have more localized effects (Baumard and Starbuck, 2005). Thus a failed technological investment may have no implications for future efforts to enter a new geographic market, but it might have an effect on future knowledge generation efforts even in different industries.

Second, the failure would have to be of a size that is both large enough and not too large. On one hand, research on learning from failure has shown significantly greater potential to learn from smaller failures than from larger ones (Sitkin, 1992; Cannon and Edmondson, 2001). Large failures would be more likely to result in organizational failure or a comprehensive turnover in management, both of which would limit any sort of observable response. On the other hand, failures that are too small would not have enough visibility in the organization to cause senior managers to change decision-making behavior. Therefore I would expect a nonlinear (inverted U-shaped) relationship between the size of the failure and the observed inertia.

Third, the organizational response might differ based on the perceived cause of failure. In the industry studied in this research, the source of failure was largely exogenous: LCD developed faster than plasma due to inherent qualities of the technology, not due to mistakes made by firms. As such, it can be difficult to assign blame for failure (Lant, Milliken, and Batra, 1992), which may lead to inefficient attempts to respond to failure (Husted and Michailova, 2002). In cases in which the failure is more clearly endogenous and blame can be allocated to a single person, the organizational response may be simply to remove that person from the organization and make no other changes. The results would be little or no inertia.

Fourth, I would expect the inertial effect of prior failure to dissipate over time. Research on learning and memory in organizations has generally shown that the effect of prior experiences will decay over time (Walsh and Ungson, 1991; Cohen and Bacdayan, 1994; Ingram and Baum, 1997). From this study, comparing the results of the various robustness checks that involved shortening the ending point of the panel model all produced stronger inertial results than the ones reported in the full model, suggesting that the effect did dissipate over time in this study. But, of course, the finding that firms initially investing in plasma in the 1960s and 1970s were averse to reinvesting in plasma in the 1990s suggests that the effect of failure does not dissipate immediately.

Finally, the effect of a prior failure will depend on the exact future responsibilities and autonomy of the person responsible for making the initial failed investment. If the original decision maker is the same person making the subsequent decision and that person has the same degree of autonomy at the time of the subsequent decision, then I expect to see the risk-seeking behavior outlined in prospect theory (Kahneman and Tversky, 1979; Thaler and Johnson, 1990) and the behavioral theory of the firm (Cyert and March, 1963; March and Shapira, 1987). Thus, for any given individual, an early failure experience may lead to a future acceleration of activity. This perspective presents a picture of managers out to validate the initial decision to pursue the new technological market in the first place, whatever the organizational and financial cost. As discussed earlier, this circumstance seems unlikely in a traditional hierarchical organizational setting, but there may be specific circumstances (such as sequential decisions with little time separating them) in which this may be the case. Overall, these five boundary conditions—similarity, size, cause, time, and autonomy—present a view of when we may expect to see the inertial behavior exhibited in this study, but they are merely suggestions based on prior theory and the results of this very specific study. Future research would need to ascertain the validity and the exact nature of these limiting factors, and how firms that fall flat in betting on the losing technology can dust themselves off and move forward.

bio.p: J. P. Eggers is an assistant professor of management and organization at New York University’s Stern School of Business, 40 West 4th Street, Tisch 715, New York, NY 10012 (e-mail: jeggers@stern.nyu.edu). His research focuses on decision making under uncertainty, especially the uncertainty resulting from technological dynamics or from the decision to enter an unknown market space. He received his doctorate in strategy from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania.

One advantage of Derwent is that professional patent analysts look at each individual patent and assign it to one or more of Derwent’s “manual codes.” There are, for example, dozens of manual codes applying to LCD patents. The USPTO, in contrast, sometimes groups patents together by end purpose (i.e., televisions), without clear respect for the underlying technology. Derwent also provides this finer-grained level of classification back to 1963, while the USPTO only provides searchable data through 1975.

An alternative specification, with a first-stage selection model and the inclusion of an inverse Mills ratio in the second stage, produces similar results. Because implementing a Heckman correction with a count model can bias the results (Greene, 2001), I focused on the specification discussed later.

In many technology studies, technology licensing activity may play a significant role in understanding future investment. Licensing would suggest that firms may use different strategies and that patent counts may not always correlate with investment in the industry. Unfortunately, data are not available on technology licensing to use as a control variable. My qualitative research in this industry suggests that licensing was very uncommon in the early stages of the industry, only becoming a viable strategy in the early 1990s.

I used a cutoff of 80 percent because this ensures that the population of early entrants is split into three roughly even groups. The empirical results, however, are robust to any cutoff that ensures a reasonable number of firms in each group, as well as to using continuous measures of patenting in the different technologies (as done with the share LCD at entry variable and in alternate specifications omitted for the sake of brevity).

As an alternate specification, models with a simple lagged DV (instead of a stock of the DV) produced qualitatively similar results. The same is true if the plasma patent stock variable is changed to a count of patents in t-1, as well.

This could be interpreted as a sign that investment in plasma was a good thing for LCD knowledge creation, but there are two reasons to doubt this claim. First, most early plasma supporters later abandoned plasma completely, meaning that much of the growth in the plasma patent stock variable is coming from early LCD supporters that later added plasma to their portfolio or late entrants to the industry. Second, an interaction term (not reported here) between enter with plasma and plasma patent stock is negative, though just outside of significance. This suggests that firms other than early plasma supporters largely reaped the benefits for LCD knowledge creation from simultaneous patenting in plasma.
